cleaned_text: COVID-19 vaccine This article may require [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2) intended to provide [acquired immunity](/wiki/Acquired_immunity) against severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 ( [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2)), the virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 ( [COVID19](/wiki/COVID-19)). Prior to the [COVID19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID%E2%80%9119_pandemic), an established body of knowledge existed about the structure and function of [coronaviruses](/wiki/Coronavirus) causing diseases like severe acute respiratory syndrome ( [SARS](/wiki/SARS)) and Middle East respiratory syndrome ( [MERS](/wiki/MERS)). This knowledge accelerated the development of various [vaccine platforms](/wiki/Vaccine_platform) during early 2020. [[1]](#cite_note-pmid33341119-1) The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic, often severe illness. [[2]](#cite_note-2) In 2020, the first COVID19 vaccines were developed and made available to the public through emergency authorizations [[3]](#cite_note-:0-3) and conditional approvals. [[4]](#cite_note-4) [[5]](#cite_note-EU_PR_20201221-5) Initially, most COVID19 vaccines were two-dose vaccines, with the sole exception being the single-dose [Janssen COVID-19 vaccine](/wiki/Janssen_COVID-19_vaccine). [[3]](#cite_note-:0-3) However, immunity from the vaccines has been found to wane over time, requiring people to get [booster doses](/wiki/Booster_dose) of the vaccine to maintain protection against COVID19. [[3]](#cite_note-:0-3) The COVID19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the spread of COVID19 and reducing the severity and death caused by COVID19. [[3]](#cite_note-:0-3) [[6]](#cite_note-6) According to a June 2022 study, COVID19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from 8 December 2020 to 8 December 2021. [[7]](#cite_note-7) [[8]](#cite_note-8) Many countries implemented phased distribution plans that prioritized those at highest risk of complications, such as the elderly, and those at high risk of exposure and transmission, such as healthcare workers. [[9]](#cite_note-Beaumont-9) [[10]](#cite_note-Wang1-10) Common side effects of COVID19 vaccines include soreness, redness, rash, inflammation at the injection site, fatigue, headache, [myalgia](/wiki/Myalgia) (muscle pain), and [arthralgia](/wiki/Arthralgia) (joint pain), which resolve without medical treatment within a few days. [[11]](#cite_note-who-back-11) [[12]](#cite_note-:1-12) COVID-19 vaccination is safe for people who are breastfeeding. [[13]](#cite_note-breastf-13) As of 18 June 2023 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19_vaccine&action=edit), 13.42 billion doses of COVID19 vaccines have been administered worldwide based on official reports from [national public health agencies](/wiki/List_of_national_public_health_agencies). [[14]](#cite_note-Richie_2021-14) By December 2020, more than 10 billion vaccine doses had been preordered by countries, [[15]](#cite_note-mullard-15) with about half of the doses purchased by [high-income countries](/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy) comprising 14% of the world's population. [[16]](#cite_note-So-16) Despite the extremely rapid development of effective [mRNA](/wiki/MRNA_vaccine) and [viral vector vaccines](/wiki/Viral_vector_vaccine), worldwide [vaccine equity](/wiki/Vaccine_equity) has not been achieved. The development and use of [whole inactivated virus](/wiki/Whole_inactivated_virus) (WIV) and protein-based vaccines have also especially for use in [developing countries](/wiki/Developing_countries). [[17]](#cite_note-Hotez-17) [[18]](#cite_note-Ye-18) The United States [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA) has now authorized bivalent vaccines to protect against the original COVID-19 strain and its [Omicron variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant). As the same person may receive more than one dose, the number of doses can be higher than the number of people in the population. - Map showing share of population fully vaccinated against COVID-19 relative to a country's total population [[note 1]](#cite_note-OWID-notes2-20) Prior to COVID19, a vaccine for an infectious disease had never been produced in less than several years - and no vaccine existed for preventing a [coronavirus](/wiki/Coronavirus) infection in humans. [[20]](#cite_note-gates2-21) However, vaccines have been produced against several animal diseases caused by coronaviruses, including (as of 2003) [infectious coronavirus](/wiki/Canine_coronavirus), and [feline coronavirus](/wiki/Feline_coronavirus). [[21]](#cite_note-22) Previous projects to develop vaccines for viruses in the family [Coronaviridae](/wiki/Coronaviridae) that affect humans have been aimed at [severe acute respiratory syndrome](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome) (SARS) and [Middle East respiratory syndrome](/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome) (MERS). Vaccines against SARS [[22]](#cite_note-23) and MERS [[23]](#cite_note-24) have been tested in non-human [animals](/wiki/Model_organism). According to studies published in 2005 and 2006, the identification and development of novel vaccines and medicines to treat SARS was a priority for governments and [public health agencies](/wiki/List_of_national_public_health_agencies) around the world at that time. [[24]](#cite_note-PMID_15655773-25) [[25]](#cite_note-PMID_15885812-26) [[26]](#cite_note-PMID_16453264-27) There is no cure or protective vaccine proven to be safe and effective against SARS in humans. [[27]](#cite_note-JiangFutureVirology-28) [[28]](#cite_note-29) There is also no proven vaccine against MERS. [[29]](#cite_note-30) When MERS became prevalent, it was believed that existing SARS research might provide a useful template for developing vaccines and therapeutics against a MERS-CoV infection. [[27]](#cite_note-JiangFutureVirology-28) [[30]](#cite_note-Butler3oct2013-31) As of March 2020, there was one (DNA-based) MERS vaccine which completed Phase I clinical trials in humans, [[31]](#cite_note-32) and three others in progress, all being viral-vectored adenoviral-vectored (ChAdOx1-MERS, BVRS-GamVac) Vaccines that use an inactive or weakened virus that has been grown in eggs typically take more than a decade to develop. [[33]](#cite_note-Moderna_and_Pfizer_Are_Reinventing_Vaccines-34) [[34]](#cite_note-35) In contrast, mRNA is a molecule that can be made quickly, and research on mRNA to fight diseases was begun decades before the COVID19 pandemic by scientists such as [Drew Weissman](/wiki/Drew_Weissman) and [Katalin Karikó](/wiki/Katalin_Karik%C3%B3), who tested on mice. [Moderna](/wiki/Moderna) began human testing of an [mRNA vaccine](/wiki/MRNA_vaccine) in 2015. [[33]](#cite_note-Moderna_and_Pfizer_Are_Reinventing_Vaccines-34) [Viral vector vaccines](/wiki/Viral_vector_vaccine) were also developed for the COVID19 pandemic after the technology was previously cleared for Ebola. [[33]](#cite_note-Moderna_and_Pfizer_Are_Reinventing_Vaccines-34) As multiple COVID19 vaccines have been authorized or licensed for use, real-world vaccine effectiveness (RWE) is being assessed using case control and observational studies. [[35]](#cite_note-36) [[36]](#cite_note-37) A study is investigating the long-lasting protection against SARS-CoV-2 provided by the mRNA vaccines. [[37]](#cite_note-38) [[38]](#cite_note-39) Vaccine technologies As of July 2021, at least nine different technology platforms are under research and development to create an effective vaccine against COVID19. [[40]](#cite_note-thanh22-41) [[41]](#cite_note-london-42) Most of the platforms of vaccine candidates in clinical trials are focused on the [coronavirus spike protein (S protein) and its variants](/wiki/Coronavirus#Microbiology) as the primary [antigen](/wiki/Antigen) of COVID19 infection, [[40]](#cite_note-thanh22-41) since the S protein triggers strong B-cell and T-cell immune responses. [[42]](#cite_note-43) [[43]](#cite_note-Grifoni_2020-44) However, other coronavirus proteins are also being investigated for vaccine development, like the [nucleocapsid](/wiki/Nucleocapsid), because they also induce a robust T-cell response and their genes are more conserved and recombine less frequently (compared to Spike). [[43]](#cite_note-Grifoni_2020-44) [[44]](#cite_note-45) [[45]](#cite_note-46) Future generations of COVID-19 vaccines that may target more and conserved genomic regions will also act as an insurance against the manifestation of catastrophic scenarios concerning the future evolutionary path of SARS-CoV-2, or any similar Coronavirus epidemic/pandemic. [[46]](#cite_note-47) Platforms developed being developed for COVID19 are not like [influenza](/wiki/Influenza) vaccines, but rather are using "next-generation" strategies for precise targeting of COVID19 infection mechanisms. [[40]](#cite_note-thanh22-41) [[47]](#cite_note-thanh-48) [[48]](#cite_note-diamond-49) Several of the synthetic vaccines use a 2P mutation to lock the [spike protein](/wiki/Coronavirus_spike_protein) into its prefusion configuration, stimulating an [adaptive immune response](/wiki/Adaptive_immune_response) to the virus before it attaches to a human cell. [[49]](#cite_note-50) Vaccine platforms in development may improve flexibility for antigen manipulation, and effectiveness for targeting mechanisms of COVID19 infection in susceptible population subgroups, such as healthcare workers, the elderly, children, [pregnant women](/wiki/COVID%E2%80%9119_in_pregnancy), and people with weakened [immune systems](/wiki/Immune_system). [[40]](#cite_note-thanh22-41) Several COVID19 the [Pfizer-BioNTech](/wiki/Pfizer%E2%80%93BioNTech_COVID%E2%80%9119_vaccine) and [Moderna](/wiki/Moderna_COVID%E2%80%9119_vaccine) vaccines, use [RNA](/wiki/RNA) to stimulate an immune response. When introduced into human tissue, the vaccine contains either self-replicating RNA or [messenger RNA](/wiki/Messenger_RNA) (mRNA), which both cause cells to express the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. This teaches the body how to identify and destroy the corresponding pathogen. RNA vaccines often use [nucleoside-modified messenger RNA](/wiki/Nucleoside-modified_messenger_RNA). The [delivery](/wiki/Drug_delivery) of mRNA is achieved by a coformulation of the molecule into [lipid nanoparticles](/wiki/Lipid_nanoparticle) which protect the RNA strands and help their absorption into the cells. [[50]](#cite_note-51) [[51]](#cite_note-pmid33340620-52) [[52]](#cite_note-Kowalski-53) [[53]](#cite_note-Verbeke_2019-54) RNA vaccines are the first COVID19 vaccines to be authorized in the United Kingdom, the United States and the European Union. However, various other types of vaccine delivery methods have been studied for future coronavirus vaccines. Intranasal Intranasal vaccines target [mucosal immunity](/wiki/Mucosal_immunology) in the [nasal mucosa](/wiki/Nasal_mucosa) which is a portal for viral entrance to the body. [[112]](#cite_note-mudgal-113) [[113]](#cite_note-rhee-114) These vaccines are designed to stimulate nasal [immune factors](/wiki/Immune_factor), such as [IgA](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_A). [[112]](#cite_note-mudgal-113) In addition to inhibiting the virus, nasal vaccines provide ease of administration because no needles (or [needle phobia](/wiki/Fear_of_needles)) are involved. [[113]](#cite_note-rhee-114) [[114]](#cite_note-cdc-115) Nasal vaccines have been approved for [influenza](/wiki/Influenza), [[113]](#cite_note-rhee-114) [[114]](#cite_note-cdc-115) but not for COVID-19. A variety of intranasal COVID-19 vaccines are undergoing clinical trials. One is in use in China. [[115]](#cite_note-116) Examples include a vaccine candidate which uses a modified avian virus as a vector to target SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins and an mRNA vaccine delivered via a nasal nanoparticle spray. [[116]](#cite_note-117) In September 2022, India and China approved the two first [nasal](/wiki/Nasal_vaccine) COVID-19 vaccines ( [iNCOVACC](/wiki/INCOVACC) and [Convidecia](/wiki/Convidecia)) which may (as boosters) [[117]](#cite_note-118) also reduce transmission [[118]](#cite_note-naturenasalvac-119) [[119]](#cite_note-120) (potentially via sterilizing immunity). [[120]](#cite_note-Nistor_2022-121) [[121]](#cite_note-122) [[122]](#cite_note-123) Universal vaccine A universal coronavirus vaccine would be effective against all coronavirus (and possibly other) viruses. [[123]](#cite_note-124) [[124]](#cite_note-:02-125) The concept was publicly endorsed by [NIAID](/wiki/NIAID) director [virologist](/wiki/Virology) [Jeffery the [White House](/wiki/White_House) released the "National COVID-19 Preparedness Plan", which recommended development of a universal coronavirus vaccine.[ [clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify)] [[126]](#cite_note-127) One attempt at such a vaccine is being developed at [Walter Reed Army Institute of Research](/wiki/Walter_Reed_Army_Institute_of_Research). It uses a spike ferritin-based nanoparticle (SpFN). This vaccine began a Phase I clinical trial in April 2022. [[127]](#cite_note-128) Another strategy is to attach vaccine fragments from multiple strains to a [nanoparticle](/wiki/Nanoparticle) scaffold. Universality is enhanced by targeting the receptor-binding domain rather than the [spike protein](/wiki/Spike_protein). [[128]](#cite_note-129) Formulation As of September 2020 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19_vaccine&action=edit), eleven of the vaccine candidates in clinical development use [adjuvants](/wiki/Adjuvants) to enhance immunogenicity. [[40]](#cite_note-thanh22-41) An [immunological adjuvant](/wiki/Immunological_adjuvant) is a substance formulated with a vaccine to elevate the immune response to an [antigen](/wiki/Antigen), such as the COVID19 virus or influenza virus. [[129]](#cite_note-tregoning-130) Specifically, an adjuvant may be used in formulating a COVID19 vaccine candidate to boost its immunogenicity and efficacy to reduce or prevent COVID19 infection in vaccinated individuals. [[129]](#cite_note-tregoning-130) [[130]](#cite_note-wang-131) Adjuvants used in COVID19 vaccine formulation may be particularly effective for technologies using the inactivated COVID19 virus and recombinant protein-based or vector-based vaccines. [[130]](#cite_note-wang-131) Aluminum salts, known as " [alum](/wiki/Alum)", were the first adjuvant used for licensed vaccines, and are the adjuvant of choice in some 80% of adjuvanted vaccines. [[130]](#cite_note-wang-131) The alum adjuvant initiates diverse molecular and cellular mechanisms to enhance immunogenicity, including release of proinflammatory cytokines. [[129]](#cite_note-tregoning-130) [[130]](#cite_note-wang-131) Planning and development Since January 2020, vaccine development has been expedited via unprecedented collaboration in the [multinational pharmaceutical industry](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry) and between governments. [[40]](#cite_note-thanh22-41) Multiple steps along the entire development path are evaluated, including: [[20]](#cite_note-gates2-21) [[131]](#cite_note-simpson-132) - the level of acceptable toxicity of the vaccine (its safety), - targeting vulnerable populations, - the need for vaccine efficacy breakthroughs, - the duration of vaccination protection, - special delivery systems (such as oral or nasal, rather than by injection), - dose regimen, - stability and storage characteristics, - emergency use authorization before formal licensing, - optimal manufacturing for scaling to billions of doses, and - dissemination of the licensed vaccine. Challenges There have been several unique challenges with COVID19 vaccine development. Public health programs[ [who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] have been described as in "[a] race to vaccinate individuals" with the early wave vaccines. [[132]](#cite_note-133) Timelines for conducting clinical research - normally a sequential process requiring years - are being compressed into safety, efficacy, and dosing trials running simultaneously over months, potentially compromising safety assurance. [[133]](#cite_note-sanger-134) [[134]](#cite_note-reuters-135) For example, Chinese vaccine developers and the government [Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Chinese_Center_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) began their efforts in January 2020, [[135]](#cite_note-136) and by March were pursuing numerous candidates on short timelines. [[133]](#cite_note-sanger-134) [[136]](#cite_note-wee-137) The rapid development and urgency of producing a vaccine for the COVID19 pandemic was expected to increase the risks and failure rate of delivering a safe, effective vaccine. [[47]](#cite_note-thanh-48) [[48]](#cite_note-diamond-49) [[137]](#cite_note-Thorp-138) Additionally, research at universities is obstructed by [physical distancing](/wiki/Social_distancing) and closing of laboratories. [[138]](#cite_note-139) [[139]](#cite_note-140) Vaccines must progress through several phases of [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trial) to test for safety, [immunogenicity](/wiki/Immunogenicity), effectiveness, dose levels and [adverse effects](/wiki/Vaccine_adverse_event) of the candidate vaccine. [[140]](#cite_note-Vaccines.gov-141) [[141]](#cite_note-fda-ddp-142) Vaccine developers have to invest resources internationally to find enough participants for Phase II-III clinical trials when the virus has proved to be a " [moving target](/wiki/Moving_target_indication)" of changing transmission rates across and within countries, forcing companies to compete for trial participants. [[142]](#cite_note-cohen6-19-143) Clinical trial organizers also may encounter people unwilling to be vaccinated due to [vaccine hesitancy](/wiki/Vaccine_hesitancy) [[143]](#cite_note-dube-144) or disbelief in the science of the vaccine technology and its ability to prevent infection. [[144]](#cite_note-howard-cnn-145) As new vaccines are developed during the COVID19 pandemic, licensure of COVID19 vaccine candidates[ [who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] requires submission of a full dossier of information on development and manufacturing quality. [[145]](#cite_note-ema-eau-146) [[146]](#cite_note-byrne10-19-147) [[147]](#cite_note-dangerfield-148) Organizations Internationally, the [Access to is a [G20](/wiki/G20) and [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) initiative announced in April 2020. [[148]](#cite_note-g20gm-149) [[149]](#cite_note-whopress-150) It is a cross-discipline support structure to enable partners to share resources and knowledge. It comprises four pillars, each managed by two to three collaborating partners: Vaccines (also called " [COVAX](/wiki/COVAX)"), Diagnostics, Therapeutics, and Health Systems Connector. The WHO vaccine coalition will prioritize which vaccines should go into Phase II and III clinical trials, and determine harmonized Phase III protocols for all vaccines achieving the [pivotal trial](/wiki/Pivotal_trial) stage.
